moves.1. Nf3 d5 2. c4: The Reti opening. As in the Queen's Gambit, White is trying to remove Black's QP and thereby lessen his control over e4.
moves.2... d4: The Main Line, but other moves are playable: 2...dxc4, 2...c6, 2...e6.
moves.3. d3 c5 4. b4: A gambit, designed to weaken the pawn on d4, but the more conservative 4.g3 is probably better.
moves.4... cxb4 5. a3: Hoping you will capture again and enable him to develop one of his pieces.
moves.5... Qa5: You did right not to capture, but this gives up the pawn on d4 for nothing. Both 5...e6 and 5...b3 have yielded good results.
moves.6... e6: 6...Nc6, defending both pawns, is better (or you could play 6...e5).
moves.7. Nxd4: Material is level again, but White has control of the centre and Black can't do much about it due to the absence of his c and d pawns.
moves.8. Nb5: The simple 8.Nb3 was better. I don't think he looked far enough ahead.
moves.8... Qxa1 9. Nc7+ Kd8 10. Nxa8: White has regained his rook, but how does he extricate his knight?
moves.10... bxa3: Black now has a very dangerous pawn.
moves.11. Bf4: White tries to extricate his knight, but it was more important to counter the threat of the pawn.
moves.11... Bb4+: The immediate 11...e2 is best, but this also wins.
moves.13. Kxd1 a2 14. Be5 Nc6 15. Bxg7: 15.Bb2 would have made it more difficult for you.
